document_data.name: Thunderherder
document_data.mainbody: '''Thunderherders''', otherwise known as '''ashworms''', were a rare species of large [[worm]]-like creatures, distantly related to the more infamous [[purple worm]]. Their name was derived from the approach of their herds eliciting a sound reminiscent of thunder.
document_data.Description: On average, the body of a thunderherder grew to be {{SIrange|3|5|ft|long=yes}} wide and {{SIrange|5|10|ft|long=yes}} in length. Their bodies were covered in a thin layer of chitinous, pale purple plates. On one end of their body was a large, stinger.
document_data.Behavior: Unlike their cousin the purple worm, thunderherders were relatively non-aggressive creatures.
document_data.Biology:
Thunderherders secreted a substance from their bodies that allowed them to stick to vertical surfaces. Their large stinger was [[poison]]ous.

Thunderherders could carry very heavy loads of supplies. A small load for them was roughly equal to and below {{SI|500|lbs|k}}, a medium load capped off at {{SI|900|lbs|k}}, and the heaviest load they could manage was {{SI|1400|lbs|k}}. However, they were capable of dragging upwards of {{SI|6900|lbs.|k}}.
document_data.Combat: When engaging a creature in combat, thunderherders would rise from the earth and coil themselves. They would then lash out with their large stinger.

Ecology.Habitats:
Thunderherders were only known to be found within the deserts or plains of warm regions.

In the Realms, they were primarily known to inhabit the [[Raurin desert]].
Ecology.Relationships:
The movement of their bodies typically caused tremors in the earth that would cause confusion above ground and panic pack animals. Even the movement of a single thunderherder could unleash small tremors in an area.

Some creatures were known to capture and train thunderherders for use as [[mount]]s. When this was done, a trainer typically clipped off their dangerous stingers. They were often difficult to control in combat situations.
